The Parliament of the United Kingdom is the supreme legislative body of the United Kingdom, and the British overseas territories. It alone possesses legislative supremacy and thereby ultimate power over all other political bodies in the UK and the overseas territories. Parliament is bicameral but has three parts, consisting of the sovereign (Crown-in-Parliament), the House of Lords, and the House of Commons (the primary chamber). The two houses meet in the Palace of Westminster in the City of Westminster, one of the inner boroughs of the capital city, London.
The House of Lords includes two different types of members: the Lords Spiritual, consisting of the most senior bishops of the Church of England; and the Lords Temporal, consisting mainly of life peers, appointed by the sovereign, and of 92 hereditary peers, sitting either by virtue of holding a royal office, or by being elected by their fellow hereditary peers. Prior to the opening of the Supreme Court in October 2009, the House of Lords also performed a judicial role through the Law Lords.
The House of Commons is an elected chamber with elections to 650 single member constituencies held at least every five years under the first-past-the-post system. The two houses meet in separate chambers in the Palace of Westminster. By constitutional convention, all government ministers, including the prime minister, are members of the House of Commons or, less commonly, the House of Lords and are thereby accountable to the respective branches of the legislature. Most cabinet ministers are from the Commons, whilst junior ministers can be from either house.
The Parliament of Great Britain was formed in 1707 following the ratification of the Treaty of Union by Acts of Union passed by the Parliament of England and the Parliament of Scotland, both Acts of Union stating, 'That the United Kingdom of Great Britain be represented by one and the same Parliament to be styled The Parliament of Great Britain.' At the start of the 19th century, Parliament was further enlarged by Acts of Union ratified by the Parliament of Great Britain and the Parliament of Ireland that abolished the latter and added 100 Irish MPs and 32 Lords to the former to create the Parliament of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland. The Royal and Parliamentary Titles Act 1927 formally amended the name to the 'Parliament of the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland', five years after the secession of the Irish Free State.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Parliament_of_the_United_Kingdom

questions.explanation: In the 2nd paragraph, it states that the House of Commons has elections for 650 single member constituencies – therefore only 650 members are elected. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.explanation: In the last paragraph, it states that Parliamentary Titles Act of 1927 was amended 5 years after the Irish Free State secession – therefore 5 years before 1927 is 1922 – so it is possible the secession occurred in 1922. Therefore, the answer is A.

The O. J. Simpson murder case was a criminal trial held in Los Angeles County Superior Court. Former National Football League (NFL) player, broadcaster, and actor O. J. Simpson was tried on two counts of murder for the June 12, 1994 slashing deaths of his ex-wife, Nicole Brown Simpson, and her friend Ron Goldman. At 12:10 a.m. on June 13, 1994, Brown and Goldman were found stabbed to death outside her condominium in the Brentwood neighbourhood of Los Angeles. Simpson became a person of interest after police found a bloody glove behind his house and was formally charged with the murders on the morning of June 17. When he did not turn himself in at the agreed time (having previously been released after perfunctory questioning by police detectives), he became the object of a low-speed pursuit in a white 1993 Ford Bronco SUV owned and driven by his friend Al Cowlings. TV stations interrupted coverage of the NBA finals to broadcast the incident. The pursuit was watched live by an estimated 95 million people. The pursuit, arrest, and trial were among the most widely publicized events in American history. The trial—often characterized as the trial of the century because of its international publicity—spanned eleven months, from the jury's swearing-in on November 9, 1994. Opening statements were made on January 24, 1995, and the verdict was announced on October 3, 1995, when Simpson was acquitted on two counts of murder. According to USA Today, the case has been described as the 'most publicized' criminal trial in history.
Simpson was represented by a high-profile defense team, also referred to as the 'Dream Team', which was initially led by Robert Shapiro and subsequently directed by Johnnie Cochran. The team also included F. Lee Bailey, Alan Dershowitz, Robert Kardashian, Shawn Holley, Carl E. Douglas, and Gerald Uelmen. Barry Scheck and Peter Neufeld were two additional attorneys who specialized in DNA evidence.
Deputy District Attorneys Marcia Clark, William Hodgman and later Christopher Darden thought that they had a strong case against Simpson, but Cochran was able to convince the jury that there was reasonable doubt concerning the validity of the State's DNA evidence, which was a relatively new form of evidence in trials at that time. The reasonable doubt theory included evidence that the blood sample had allegedly been mishandled by lab scientists and technicians, and there were questionable circumstances that surrounded other court exhibits. Cochran and the defense team also alleged other misconduct by the LAPD related to systemic racism and the actions of Detective Mark Fuhrman. Simpson's celebrity status, racial issues, and the lengthy televised trial riveted national attention.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/O._J._Simpson_murder_case

We do not know if the reason they gave for the characterisation was the ONLY reason. Therefore, the answer is C.

Matchlock firearms were used in India by 1500, in Đại Việt by 1516, and in Southeast Asia by 1540. According to a Burmese source from the late 15th century, King Meng Khoum II would not dare attack the besieged town of Prome due to the defenders' use of cannon and small arms that were described as muskets, although these were probably early matchlock arquebuses or wall guns.
The Portuguese may have introduced muskets to Sri Lanka during their conquest of the coastline and low lands in 1505, as they regularly used short barreled matchlocks during combat. However, P.E.P.Deraniyagala points out that the Sinhalese term for gun, 'bondikula', matches the Arabic term for gun, 'bunduk'. Also, certain technical aspects of the early Sinhalese matchlock were similar to the matchlocks used in the Middle East, thus forming the generally accepted theory that the musket was not entirely new to the island by the time the Portuguese came. In any case, soon native Sri Lankan kingdoms, most notably the kingdom of Sitawaka and the Kandyan Kingdom, manufactured hundreds of Sinhalese muskets, with a unique bifurcated stock, longer barrel and smaller calibre, which made it more efficient in directing and using the energy of the gunpowder. These were mastered by native soldiers to the point where, according to the Portuguese chronicler, Queirós, they could 'fire at night to put out a match' and 'by day at 60 paces would sever a knife with four or five bullets' and 'send as many on the same spot in the target.'
Arquebuses were imported by the Ming Dynasty (1368–1644) at an uncertain point, but the Ming only began fielding matchlocks in 1548. The Chinese used the term 'bird-gun' to refer to arquebuses and Turkish arquebuses may have reached China before Portuguese ones. In Zhao Shizhen's book of 1598 AD, the Shenqipu, there were illustrations of Ottoman Turkish musketmen with detailed illustrations of their muskets, alongside European musketeers with detailed illustrations of their muskets. There was also illustration and description of how the Chinese had adopted the Ottoman kneeling position in firing while using European-made muskets, though Zhao Shizhen described the Turkish muskets as being superior to the European muskets. The Wu Pei Chih (1621) later described Turkish muskets that used a rack-and-pinion mechanism, which was not known to have been used in any European or Chinese firearms at the time
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Musket

A pearl is a hard, glistening object produced within the soft tissue (specifically the mantle) of a living shelled mollusk or another animal, such as fossil conulariids. Just like the shell of a mollusk, a pearl is composed of calcium carbonate (in a pearl, mainly aragonite or a mixture of aragonite and calcite) in minute crystalline form, which has been deposited in concentric layers. The ideal pearl is perfectly round and smooth, but many other shapes, known as baroque pearls, can occur. The finest quality of natural pearls have been highly valued as gemstones and objects of beauty for many centuries. Because of this, pearl has become a metaphor for something rare, fine, admirable and valuable.
The most valuable pearls occur spontaneously in the wild, but are extremely rare. These wild pearls are referred to as natural pearls. Cultured or farmed pearls from pearl oysters and freshwater mussels make up the majority of those currently sold. Imitation pearls are also widely sold in inexpensive jewellery, but the quality of their iridescence is usually very poor and is easily distinguished from that of genuine pearls. Pearls have been harvested and cultivated primarily for use in jewellery, but in the past were also used to adorn clothing. They have also been crushed and used in cosmetics, medicines and paint formulations.
Whether wild or cultured, gem-quality pearls are almost always nacreous and iridescent, like the interior of the shell that produces them. However, almost all species of shelled mollusks are capable of producing pearls (technically 'calcareous concretions') of lesser shine or less spherical shape. Although these may also be legitimately referred to as 'pearls' by gemological labs and also under U.S. Federal Trade Commission rules, and are formed in the same way, most of them have no value except as curiosities.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pearl

questions.explanation: The aragonite and calcite mixture composition is stated to be “in a pearl”, however we do not know if the calcium carbonate in the shell of a mollusk shares this. Therefore, the answer is C.

Therefore at least 1 species cannot do so (due to the word ‘almost’). Therefore, the answer is B.

A genetically modified organism (GMO) is any organism whose genetic material has been altered using genetic engineering techniques. The exact definition of a genetically modified organism and what constitutes genetic engineering varies, with the most common being an organism altered in a way that 'does not occur naturally by mating and/or natural recombination'. A wide variety of organisms have been genetically modified (GM), from animals to plants and microorganisms. Genes have been transferred within the same species, across species (creating transgenic organisms) and even across kingdoms. New genes can be introduced, or endogenous genes can be enhanced, altered or knocked out.
Creating a genetically modified organism is a multi-step process. Genetic engineers must isolate the gene they wish to insert into the host organism and combine it with other genetic elements, including a promoter and terminator region and often a selectable marker. A number of techniques are available for inserting the isolated gene into the host genome. Recent advancements using genome editing techniques, notably CRISPR, have made the production of GMO's much simpler. Herbert Boyer and Stanley Cohen made the first genetically modified organism in 1973, a bacteria resistant to the antibiotic kanamycin. The first genetically modified animal, a mouse, was created in 1974 by Rudolf Jaenisch, and the first plant was produced in 1983. In 1994 the Flavr Savr tomato was released, the first commercialized genetically modified food. The first genetically modified animal to be commercialized was the GloFish (2003) and the first genetically modified animal to be approved for food use was the AquAdvantage salmon in 2015.
Bacteria are the easiest organisms to engineer and have been used for research, food production, industrial protein purification (including drugs), agriculture, and art. There is potential to use them for environmental, purposes or as medicine. Fungi have been engineered with much the same goals. Viruses play an important role as vectors for inserting genetic information into other organisms. This use is especially relevant to human gene therapy. There are proposals to remove the virulent genes from viruses to create vaccines. Plants have been engineered for scientific research, to create new colours in plants, deliver vaccines and to create enhanced crops. Genetically modified crops are publicly the most controversial GMOs. The majority are engineered for herbicide tolerance or insect resistance. Golden rice has been engineered with three genes that increase its nutritional value. Other prospects for GM crops are as bioreactors for the production of biopharmaceuticals, biofuels or medicines.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetically_modified_organism

Down syndrome or Down's syndrome, also known as trisomy 21, is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of all or part of a third copy of chromosome 21. It is usually associated with physical growth delays, mild to moderate intellectual disability, and characteristic facial features. The average IQ of a young adult with Down syndrome is 50, equivalent to the mental ability of an 8- or 9-year-old child, but this can vary widely.
The parents of the affected individual are usually genetically normal. The probability increases from less than 0.1% in 20-year-old mothers to 3% in those of age 45. The extra chromosome is believed to occur by chance, with no known behavioural activity or environmental factor that changes the probability. Down syndrome can be identified during pregnancy by prenatal screening followed by diagnostic testing or after birth by direct observation and genetic testing. Since the introduction of screening, pregnancies with the diagnosis are often terminated. Regular screening for health problems common in Down syndrome is recommended throughout the person's life.
There is no cure for Down syndrome. Education and proper care have been shown to improve quality of life. Some children with Down syndrome are educated in typical school classes, while others require more specialized education. Some individuals with Down syndrome graduate from high school, and a few attend post-secondary education. In adulthood, about 20% in the United States do paid work in some capacity, with many requiring a sheltered work environment. Support in financial and legal matters is often needed. Life expectancy is around 50 to 60 years in the developed world with proper health care.
Down syndrome is the most common chromosome abnormality in humans. It occurs in about 1 in 1,000 babies born each year. In 2015, Down syndrome was present in 5.4 million individuals globally and resulted in 27,000 deaths, down from 43,000 deaths in 1990.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Down_syndrome

Therefore, the answer is C.

questions.explanation: Although we know the life expectancy of those with Down syndrome in the developed world, we have no information about the undeveloped world. This question invites assumptions. Therefore, the answer is C.

The Spanish flu pandemic of 1918, the deadliest in history, infected an estimated 500 million people worldwide—about one-third of the planet’s population—and killed an estimated 20 million to 50 million victims, including some 675,000 Americans. The 1918 flu was first observed in Europe, the United States and parts of Asia before swiftly spreading around the world. At the time, there were no effective drugs or vaccines to treat this killer flu strain. Citizens were ordered to wear masks, schools, theatres and businesses were shuttered and bodies piled up in makeshift morgues before the virus ended its deadly global march.
The first wave of the 1918 pandemic occurred in the spring and was generally mild. The sick, who experienced such typical flu symptoms as chills, fever and fatigue, usually recovered after several days, and the number of reported deaths was low. However, a second, highly contagious wave of influenza appeared with a vengeance in the fall of that same year. Victims died within hours or days of developing symptoms, their skin turning blue and their lungs filling with fluid that caused them to suffocate. In just one year, 1918, the average life expectancy in America plummeted by a dozen years.
One unusual aspect of the 1918 flu was that it struck down many previously healthy, young people—a group normally resistant to this type of infectious illness—including a number of World War I servicemen. In fact, more U.S. soldiers died from the 1918 flu than were killed in battle during the war. Forty percent of the U.S. Navy was hit with the flu, while 36 percent of the Army became ill, and troops moving around the world in crowded ships and trains helped to spread the killer virus.
Although the death toll attributed to the Spanish flu is often estimated at 20 million to 50 million victims worldwide, other estimates run as high as 100 million victims—around 3 percent of the world’s population. The exact numbers are impossible to know due to a lack of medical record-keeping in many places. What is known, however, is that few locations were immune to the 1918 flu—in America, victims ranged from residents of major cities to those of remote Alaskan communities.
Source: https://www.history.com/topics/world-war-i/1918-flu-pandemic

Solo is an Australian lemon-flavoured soft drink currently manufactured under license by Asahi Beverages. Launched in 1968 - first in a bottle, then in a 375ml can, by Tarax drinks. It is a ready to drink version of traditional 'pub squash'. There are various versions of Solo available, including Solo Zero, which uses artificial sweetener instead of sugar and also a Lemon&Lime flavoured variant of the original recipe. The original Solo can was designed for DDB Needham Melbourne (Creative Director - Noel Schoelbridge) formally Hughes Satchwell by Les Mason Design (Simon Josephson Designer and Bill Quan Production).
Positioned as a highly masculine drink, Solo presents an overtly male image in its aggressive television commercials. The 'Solo man' character (acted by Michael Ace, PE Teacher)and slogans 'The thirst crusher' and 'Light on the fizz, so you can slam it down fast' were used in advertising until the early 1990s. The commercials often featured scenes of men taking part in activities such as athletics or extreme sports. Since becoming a sponsor of the Football Federation of Australia, the slogan 'Game On' has been used.
In 2012, the Solo man was revived by the advertising agency BMF as part of a new Solo advertising campaign
Cadbury Schweppes sold a similar citrus drink named Rondo in the United States market during the late 1970s and 80s. Like Solo, Rondo's marketing was positioned as a similarly masculine drink. Its aggressive commercials were parodied in the 2006 film Idiocracy as 'Brawndo: The Thirst Mutilator'.
Using the Australian Solo as an inspiration, Cadbury Schweppes has also sold an energy drink in the U.S. called Coolah Energy. It used the tagline 'Energy from Down Under'. It listed boronia as an ingredient, a citrus plant in Australia known more worldwide for use in floral arrangements than its fruit. Coolah Energy has since been discontinued.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Solo_(Australian_soft_drink)

Enzymes are both proteins and biological catalysts (biocatalysts). Catalysts accelerate chemical reactions. The molecules upon which enzymes may act are called substrates, and the enzyme converts the substrates into different molecules known as products. Almost all metabolic processes in the cell need enzyme catalysis in order to occur at rates fast enough to sustain life. Metabolic pathways depend upon enzymes to catalyse individual steps. The study of enzymes is called enzymology and a new field of pseudo enzyme analysis has recently grown up, recognising that during evolution, some enzymes have lost the ability to carry out biological catalysis, which is often reflected in their amino acid sequences and unusual 'pseudo catalytic' properties.
Enzymes are known to catalyse more than 5,000 biochemical reaction types. Other biocatalysts are catalytic RNA molecules, called ribozymes. Enzymes' specificity comes from their unique three-dimensional structures.
Like all catalysts, enzymes increase the reaction rate by lowering its activation energy. Some enzymes can make their conversion of substrate to product occur many millions of times faster. An extreme example is orotidine 5'-phosphate decarboxylase, which allows a reaction that would otherwise take millions of years to occur in milliseconds. Chemically, enzymes are like any catalyst and are not consumed in chemical reactions, nor do they alter the equilibrium of a reaction. Enzymes differ from most other catalysts by being much more specific. Enzyme activity can be affected by other molecules: inhibitors are molecules that decrease enzyme activity, and activators are molecules that increase activity. Many therapeutic drugs and poisons are enzyme inhibitors. An enzyme's activity decreases markedly outside its optimal temperature and pH, and many enzymes are (permanently) denatured when exposed to excessive heat, losing their structure and catalytic properties.
Some enzymes are used commercially, for example, in the synthesis of antibiotics. Some household products use enzymes to speed up chemical reactions: enzymes in biological washing powders break down protein, starch or fat stains on clothes, and enzymes in meat tenderizer break down proteins into smaller molecules, making the meat easier to chew.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Enzyme

Therefore, it can be inferred that enzymes increase the speed at which chemical reactions go; ie. lowering the time for the reaction. Therefore, the answer is D.

Hadrian’s Wall is the remains of stone fortifications built by the Roman Empire following its conquest of Britain in the second century A.D. The original structure stretched more than 70 miles across the northern English countryside from the River Tyne near the city of Newcastle and the North Sea, west to the Irish Sea. Hadrian’s Wall included a number of forts as well as a ditch designed to protect against invading troops. The remnants of a stone wall are still visible in many places.
Contrary to popular belief, Hadrian’s Wall does not, nor has it ever, served as the border between England and Scotland, two of the four countries that make up the United Kingdom. However, it does hold significance as a UNESCO World Heritage site and a major tourist attraction.
Hadrian’s Wall is located near the border between modern-day Scotland and England. It runs in an east-west direction, from Wallsend and Newcastle on the River Tyne in the east, traveling about 73 miles west to Bowness-on-Solway on Solway Firth. The wall took at least six years to complete. Construction started at the east end and moved westward. The work was completed by Roman soldiers.
Historians believe the original plan was to build a wall of stone or turf, fronted by a wide, deep ditch. The wall would feature a guarded gate every mile, with two observation towers in between each gate. Ultimately, 14 forts were added to the wall, and were augmented by an “earthwork” known as the Vallum to the south. It is essentially a large mound designed to serve as another defensive bulwark. Hadrian’s Wall was named a UNESCO World Heritage site in 1987. It remains unguarded, meaning tourists visiting the site have unfettered access, despite concerns over damage. More recently, when London hosted the Summer Olympics in 2012, Hadrian’s Wall was part of an art installation called “Connecting Light.”
Source: https://www.history.com/topics/ancient-rome/hadrians-wall

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be true about Hadrian’s Wall?
options: Protective features of the Wall included several forts and a ditch at its rear
The Romanian empire constructed the wall to protect itself purely from British troops
The wall was a protective mechanism erected by the Romans as a form of defence
The wall was constructed in exactly 6 years
questions.explanation: The passage states in paragraph 1 that the wall was a fortification built by the Roman Empire – which implies that it was a form of defence. Therefore, the best answer is C.

questions.text: Regarding the current status of Hadrian’s Wall, which of the following is most likely to be true?
options: Hadrian’s Wall is no longer a UNESCO World Heritage site
The wall has never lined the border of modern-day Scotland and England
Due to concerns over damage, the site is partially restricted to tourists
The wall was featured in London during the Summer Olympics
questions.explanation: Paragraph 4 states that when London hosted the Summer Olympics in 2012, the wall was featured in an art installation called ‘Connecting Light’. Therefore the answer is D.

questions.text: All of the following are false about the original plan of the wall except:
options: The original plan to build Hadrian’s Wall featured both stone and turf
More than seventy guarded gates would line the wall
A wall was fronted by a long, narrow ditch
questions.explanation: Given that “the wall would feature a guarded gate every mile”, and we know that the original structure “stretched more than 70 miles”, it can be inferred that at least 70 guards would line the wall. Therefore, the answer is B.

questions.text: Which of the following is most likely to be false about Hadrian’s Wall?
options: It took seven years to build Hadrian’s Wall
The wall was constructed from its east end to its west end by slaves
Only parts of the wall are still remaining to be seen by tourists
The wall is located in the United Kingdom
questions.explanation: The passage states that “the work was completed by Roman soldiers”, therefore the answer is B, as slaves did not construct the wall.

stems.text:
Coronaviruses are a group of related viruses that cause diseases in mammals and birds. In humans, coronaviruses cause respiratory tract infections that can range from mild to lethal. Mild illnesses include some cases of the common cold (which has other possible causes, predominantly rhinoviruses), while more lethal varieties can cause SARS, MERS, and COVID-19. Symptoms in other species vary: in chickens, they cause an upper respiratory tract disease, while in cows and pigs they cause diarrhea. There are yet to be vaccines or antiviral drugs to prevent or treat human coronavirus infections.
Coronaviruses constitute the subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, in the family Coronaviridae, order Nidovirales, and realm Riboviria. They are enveloped viruses with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome and a nucleocapsid of helical symmetry. The genome size of coronaviruses ranges from approximately 26 to 32 kilobases, one of the largest among RNA viruses. They have characteristic club-shaped spikes that project from their surface, which in electron micrographs create an image reminiscent of the solar corona from which their name derives.
Coronaviruses are large pleomorphic spherical particles with bulbous surface projections. The average diameter of the virus particles is around 120 nm (.12 μm). The diameter of the envelope is approximately 80 nm (.08 μm) and the spikesare approximately 20 nm (.02 μm) long. The virus in electron micrographs appears as a distinct pair of electron dense shells.
The viral envelope consists of a lipid bilayer where the membrane (M), envelope (E) and spike (S) structural proteins are anchored. A subset of coronaviruses (specifically the members of betacoronavirus subgroup A) also have a shorter spike-like surface protein called hemagglutinin esterase (HE).
Inside the envelope, there is the nucleocapsid, which is formed from multiple copies of the nucleocapsid (N) protein, which are bound to the positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome in a continuous beads-on-a-string type conformation. The lipid bilayer envelope, membrane proteins, and nucleocapsid protect the virus when it is outside the host cell.
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coronavirus

questions.text: According to the passage, coronaviruses:
options: Are a group of disease causing viruses that impact only humans
Have not been observed to have an impact in animals
questions.explanation: The 3rd paragraph states that “coronaviruses are large pleomorphic spherical particles” – therefore the answer is D.

questions.text: Coronaviruses are composed of:
options: Projections into the inner shell of the viruses
questions.explanation: The final line of the passage states that “membrane proteins… protect the virus when it is outside the host call” – therefore it can be inferred that coronaviruses have protective membranous proteins. Therefore, the answer is C. The answer is not B because coronaviruses appears as electron dense shells, however that does not mean that they are composed of electron dense shells.

questions.text: In addition to spanning an average diameter of 120nm, coronaviruses as they are known currently:
options: Consist of a nuclear envelope spanning 80nm
Have spikes on their surface that are their form of weapon
Cannot cause upper respiratory tract disease in cows
Cannot be counteracted by antiviral medication
questions.explanation: The 1st paragraph states that “there are yet to be vaccines or antiviral drugs to prevent or treat human coronavirus infections”. Therefore, the answer is D.

questions.text: Which of the following are true about the nucleocapsid of coronaviruses
options: It shelters the lipid bilayer envelope
It provides a form of resistance for the virus
It has the second largest diameter of all components of the virus
questions.explanation: The final paragraph states that the nucleocapsid protects the virus when it is outside the host cell, so it is implied that it provides some sort of resistance and protection for the virus. Therefore the best answer is B.

sections.name: Decision Making
sections.description: Looks at your ability to apply logic to reach a decision or conclusion, evaluate arguments and analyse statistical information.

stems.text: Some Azzas are Bazzas. All Cazzas are Bazzas. Not all Dazzas are Azzas, but no Dazzas are Cazzas.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: If a Dazza is an Azza, it must also be a Bazza
A Cazza cannot be a Dazza
There are some Azzas that are not Dazzas
questions.explanation:
1. Whilst all Cazzas are Bazzas, that does not mean that all Bazzas are Cazzas. Therefore, if some Azzas are Bazzas, those Azzas that are Bazzas could be a part of the Bazzas that are not Cazzas. We do not know for sure. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. We know that not all Dazzas are Azzas, but that could mean that no Dazzas are Azzas as well. Thus we don’t know if most Dazzas are even Azzas. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. Only some Azzas are Bazzas, so even if a Dazza is an Azza, it is not guaranteed to also be a Bazza.
4. If no Dazzas are Cazzas, then no Cazzas are Dazzas (if a Cazza was a Dazza, that would mean a Dazza would also be a Cazza then). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. We know that not all Dazzas are Azzas, so at least 1 Dazza is not an Azza. Thus, at least 1 Azza is then also not a Dazza. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

stems.text: No athletes are taller than 6ft. All baseball players are shorter than 6ft, but most basketball players are taller than 6ft. Not all football players work full time, but athletes must work full time.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: A football player that does not work full time cannot be an athlete
If an athlete is 5ft, they cannot be a basketball player
questions.explanation:
1. Since all athletes work full time, if the football player does not work full time they cannot be an athlete. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Most basketball players are taller than 6ft, and since no athletes are taller than 6ft, most basketball players are not athletes. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. Even though all baseball players are shorter than 6ft, and no athletes are taller than 6ft, we don’t know that baseball players can even be athletes. Also, all the athletes could be 6ft exactly, in which case the baseball players could not be athletes. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Since most basketball players are taller than 6ft, at least 1 basketball player is not taller than 6ft, so they could be an athlete (since athletes are not taller than 6ft). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. We have no information about football players being athletes or any connection between the two. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

stems.text: This animal is a monkey. All monkeys have fingers, but only some animals have a tail.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: This animal cannot have a tail and fingers
questions.explanation:
1. Since only some animals have a tail, we don’t know for certain whether this animal has a tail. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Since this animal is a monkey and all monkeys have fingers, this animal will also have fingers. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. As far as we know at least 1 monkey is an animal (because this animal is a monkey), but we do not know if any monkeys have tails at all, since only some animals have tails. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. There is nothing to suggest that this animal could not have a tail, but we don’t know if it does either. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. We know at least 1 animal has fingers, since this animal is a monkey and all monkeys have fingers. Therefore, the term ‘not all’ would not be correct, as ‘not all’ includes none as well (not all could be anything but all). Since the term ‘not all’ can include 0/none, and we know at least 1 animal for certain has fingers, the answer is NO.

stems.text: Some trees grow leaves, but those which do don’t grow yellow leaves. In winter, all the leaves on trees will fall. This tree has leaves currently.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: In summer, trees will have leaves
This tree does not have yellow leaves
Some trees do not grow leaves
questions.explanation:
1. We don’t know what happens in summer. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. If in winter all the leaves will fall from the tree, and currently this tree has leaves, then it cannot be winter. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. We do not know what colour this tree’s leave are (all we know is that they are not yellow). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Since the trees that grow leaves do not grow yellow leaves, and this tree has leaves, we know this tree cannot have yellow leaves. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. If some trees grow leaves, then at least 1 tree does not grow leaves. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

stems.text: Most biscuits are vanilla cookies. Some shortbreads are biscuits, but no chocolate cookies are biscuits. All oven-baked foods are chocolate cookies.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: A food that has been oven-baked cannot be a cookie
An oven-baked food cannot be a biscuit
questions.explanation:
1. We know that all oven-baked foods are chocolate cookies, so if a food was oven-baked it must be a chocolate cookie (which is a cookie). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Even though some shortbreads are biscuits and most biscuits are vanilla cookies, at least 1 shortbread is not a biscuit, and at least 1 biscuit is not a vanilla cookie. Thus we cannot conclude that some shortbreads are vanilla cookies for certain, as all the shortbreads that are biscuits may be outside the ‘most’ biscuits that are vanilla cookies. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We do not know if oven-baking is the only way to bake, Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We do not know that chocolate cookies are the only things that have chocolates in them, and nothing suggests that biscuits cannot have chocolates in them. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. All oven-baked foods are chocolate cookies, so if a food is oven-baked it cannot be a biscuit. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

stems.text:
Amy, Benjamin, Carl and Derrick played a typing game. The winner was the person who could type a passage the fastest.
Benjamin did not type the passage the fastest.
Carl typed the passage in 40 seconds.
Amy typed the passage faster than Carl but slower than Benjamin.
Derrick came second last in the previous typing competition.

questions.text: Who typed the fastest?
questions.explanation: If Amy typed faster than Carl but slower than Benjamin, then we know Benjamin typed faster than both Amy and Carl. Since he did not type the passage the fastest, we know Derrick has to be the fastest. Therefore, the answer is D.

stems.text:
A shelter has 4 different dogs, Shelly, Guff, Mitso and Gavin. Each of the dogs are either, black, brown, white or grey.
Shelly is not brown.
The white dog has a name starting with G.
Mitso was either black or grey.

questions.text: Which of the following MUST be true?
options: The white dog is named Gavin
Guff can either be brown or white
If Gavin is white, Mitso must be black
questions.explanation: Shelly is not brown, but we do not know what colour she is. The white dog could be Gavin or Guff. If Gavin is white, then Guff is not white, but we don’t know how that affects Mitso’s colour because Guff would be black or grey. Guff can be white because he starts with G, and he could be brown (but not grey or black because if Guff is grey, then Mitso is black and Gavin is white, which leaves Shelly to be brown which she cannot. If Guff is black, then Mitso is grey, Gavin is white and Shelly is again brown which she cannot). Therefore, the answer is C.

stems.text:
In an athletics tournament, Sally, Don, Ken and Allie competed in the long jump, with the distances they made recorded.
Sally jumped more than 4.5 metres.
Ken jumped further than Sally but 2 metres less than Don.
Allie was unable to jump more than 4.5 metres.
Don jumped further than Allie.

questions.text: Who made the third highest distance?
questions.explanation: If Ken jumped further than Sally but less than Don, we know Don jumped further than Sally. If Don also jumped further than Allie we know he had the highest distance. If Allie did not jump more than 4.5m, she did not jump higher than Sally. Thus we can deduce she jumped the shortest distance. Since Ken jumped further than Sally we know she came third in height. Therefore, the answer is A.

stems.text:
Jean, Dhivyan, Bowan and Kate measured their heights and weights.
Kate was not the lightest person, but was taller than Dhivyan.
Bowan weighed less than Jean.
The person who weighed the second most was the tallest.
Bowan was taller than Kate and weighed more than her.

questions.text: Who was the tallest person?
questions.explanation: If Bowan is taller than Kate, and Kate is taller than Dhivyan, we know Bowan is at least the second tallest. Since Bowen weighed less than Jean, but weighed more than Kate who was not the lightest person, we know Bowen was the second heaviest person. Thus since the second heaviest person is the tallest, we know Bowan is the tallest. Therefore, the answer is C.

stems.text:
Adam, Ben, Caddy and Dean have 4 different cars between them – a Porsche, a Ferrari, a Nissan and a Lexus. Each have a different profession.
Adam owns either the Ferrari or Lexus.
The engineer owns the Lexus.
Caddy is a nurse, but someone else is a police officer.
Dean owns a Ferrari and is not a police officer.

questions.text: Which of the following MUST be true?
questions.explanation: If Dean owns a Ferrari, then Adam owns the Lexus which then makes him the engineer. If Dean is not a police officer, and Caddy is a nurse, then the only person remaining who could be a police officer is Ben (since Adam is the engineer). Therefore, the answer is D.

stems.text: Should people who are financially struggling be allowed to own a dog?

options: Yes, people have a right to own whatever they like
Yes, a report shows that most people who cannot afford a dog still manage to support it
No, over 40% of people who are financially struggling choose not to own a dog because they feel they can’t support it
No, they do not have enough money to support a dog as well
questions.explanation: Although both B and C refer to evidence, option B addresses the idea that the question is about, which is whether people who are financially struggling have the means to support a dog (implied), whereas C is more of a fact rather than an argument. Therefore, the answer is B.

stems.text: Should the government fine people who put non-recyclable materials in the recycling bin to encourage people to recycle correctly?

options: Yes, recycling plants will waste time sorting out non-recyclable materials, reducing the time they have to recycle
Yes, a financial disincentive would likely prevent people from incorrectly recycling things
No, this would be too impractical to implement and monitor
No, it is more effective to conduct awareness raising campaigns rather than fines
questions.explanation: Option B focuses on the problem in the question which is about people putting non-recyclable materials in the recycling bin. whereas the other options focus on irrelevant aspects of the issue or don’t even address the actual problem. Therefore, the answer is B.

stems.text: Should suburban houses have a height restriction?

options: Yes, as this would keep suburbs more aesthetic
Yes, houses that are too high have been shown to pose safety risks
No, houses with more floors and height look better
No, people should be able to decide what they do with their land
questions.explanation: Option B is the only one with evidence, and it also addresses a possible reason for having a height restriction that is logical and reasonable, whereas options A, C and D are more opinion based. Therefore, the answer is B.

stems.text: Should students not be allowed to go travelling on holiday during exam periods to improve results?

options: Yes, this would allow students to study more effectively
Yes, it has been shown that holidays disrupt a student’s studying ability
No, airfares are usually cheaper during this period
No, students should be allowed to study how and when they like
questions.explanation: Option B is the only one with evidence, and it also addresses the central idea of going on holidays improving results. Option A is similar but lacks evidence and specificity to holidays and their role in student study. Therefore, the answer is B.

stems.text: The following graph shows changing monthly average temperatures in 4 different cities, London, Tokyo, New York and Berlin over 2019.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: In January 2020, the average temperature for Berlin will be approximately -1 degree Celsius
In 2019, the monthly average temperature in the four cities followed a similar trend
In only 4 months in 2019 did at least 2 of the cities have the same monthly average temperature
Berlin is hotter on average than London
Tokyo had the highest monthly average temperature of all the four cities for every month in 2019
questions.explanation:
1. We cannot extrapolate beyond the data set given for 2019. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. The four lines follow a similar shape and temperature trends in 2019. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. In February (New York + Berlin), March (New York + London), April (Berlin + London), September (Berlin + London). Note that June/July between Tokyo and New York are close but not the same (compared to the other instances). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. This is a generalisation, which we cannot make based simply on this information in the graph. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. In June, New York had a higher temperature than Tokyo. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

stems.text: The following graph shows the population in each Australian state and territory from 1901 to 2007.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The state/territory with the highest population in 2000 was the ACT
The population of Australia in 1901 was approximately 4 million
From 1901-2007, Vic. consistently had a higher population than NSW
In 2020, the ACT will continue to have the smallest population of all the states and territories
SA and QLD had approximately the same population in 1965
questions.explanation:
1. The ACT has the smallest population in 2000 (NSW had the highest). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. The graph show the population of all the states together at 4 million in 1901. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. NSW mostly had a higher population than Vic. from 1901-2007. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We cannot extrapolate or predict from the information in the graph. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. QLD had a higher population than SA on observation of the graph in 1965. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

stems.text: The following graph shows the total sales of 3 different types of insurance packages sold by a particular company over 3 years.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: The Deluxe package is the most expensive insurance package sold by this company
Sales of Deluxe packages in 2018 were higher than sales of Platinum packages in 2019
There is an increasing trend in sales for each type of package each year
The demand for Alpha packages has increased from 2017-2019
Sale of Deluxe packages in 2017 were more than double that of Alpha packages in 2017
questions.explanation:
1. We do not know any of the prices of these packages. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. On observation, the sales of Deluxe packages in 2018 (orange) are higher than Platinum (orange). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. Deluxe has a decreasing trend in sales across the years. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. We only know that the sales have increased, however that does not mean demand has increased (maybe they increased the number of packages available). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
5. On observation the bar for Deluxe in 2017 (blue) is close to double in height than Alpha (blue). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

stems.text: The degree of change undergone by a coal as it matures from peat is known as coalification. Coalification has an important bearing on coal's physical and chemical properties and is referred to as the 'rank' of the coal. Ranking is determined by the degree of transformation of the original plant material to carbon (carbon content). The ranks of coals, from those with the least carbon to those with the most carbon, are lignite, sub-bituminous, bituminous and anthracite.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: Peat is the earliest form of coal
Coalification influences the carbon content of coal
Bituminous coal has the second highest carbon content of coal ranks
Coalification will always transform a piece of coal’s physical properties
questions.explanation:
1. Coal matures from peat, so we can infer that peat is the first form of coal. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
2. Given that the ranks of coals are ranked based on the amount of carbon in them, and then coalification is referred to as the rank of the coal, we can infer that coalification has a bearing on the carbon content of coal. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
3. If coal matures from peat, then the matured product can include lignite coal (as it is a type of coal). Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
4. We don’t know definitively if coalification will ALWAYS transform coal’s physical properties, as it can also change its chemical properties (so it may not necessarily both all the time). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.

stems.text: VOCs are a group of carbon-based chemicals that easily evaporate at room temperature. Many common household materials and products, such as paint and cleaning products, give off VOCs. Breathing low levels of VOCs for long periods of time may increase some people’s risk of health problems. Several studies suggest that exposure to VOCs may make symptoms worse in people who have asthma or are particularly sensitive to chemicals. VOCs particularly affect indoor air quality—concentrations of many VOCs are consistently higher indoors (up to 10 times higher) than outdoors.

questions.text: Place 'Yes' if the conclusion does follow. Place 'No' if the conclusion does not follow.
options: If someone breathes in VOCs, they will develop health issues
Low levels of VOCs indoors are toxic
If an asthmatic person consistently inhales VOCs, their symptoms are likely to deteriorate
If a bathroom was just painted, VOCs are likely to be present in the air
questions.explanation:
1. Although breathing VOCs increases health risks, we do not know if it causes health problems every time. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
2. Although these VOC-producing products and materials are common household things, the presence of VOCs is not certain in many households (we don’t know if they have preventative measures or things that remove VOCs). Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
3. We do not have enough information to determine whether low-levels of VOCs indoors are toxic – although they may increase health risks we not know whether the VOCs are directly toxic to humans or how the VOCs cause these health risks. Therefore, the correct answer is NO, as the conclusion does not follow.
4. Several studies suggest that exposure to VOCs may make symptoms worse in people who have asthma. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.
5. Since paint is mentioned as a VOC-producing item, we can infer that VOCs are likely to be present in the air just after painting a room. Therefore, the correct answer is YES, as the conclusion does follow.

stems.text: An election of 30 voters is held and 3 candidates, A, B, and C campaigned. The votes are as follows: 2 more people voted for only candidate A than only candidate B, only 6 people voted for both candidate B and C, no one voted for all three, and everyone voted.

questions.text: What value is X?
questions.explanation: If only 6 people voted for both B and C, then Y=6. If 2 more people voted for only candidate A than candidate B, then Z=5. Therefore if everyone voted and no one voted for all three, X=10. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

stems.text: An aquarium is made up of 4 types of fish, Lfish, Pfish, Zfish and Xfish. The following represents the different possible combinations of fish in a tank.

questions.text: Which of the following is represented by F?
questions.explanation: F is in the overlap between rectangle, square and oval, which represent Xfish, Zfish and Lfish. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

stems.text: A survey of 240 actors and doctors revealed the following diagram, comparing those that are unemployed and also paid well.

questions.text: Which of the following based on the diagram is true?
options: Some actors are unemployed but not doctors
Some doctors who are actors are paid well
Someone can be an unemployed doctor who is paid well
questions.explanation: There is an overlap between the circle and rectangle only, indicating that those actors are underpaid but not doctors (or well paid either). Therefore, the correct answer is B. Actors cannot be paid well as the rectangle and triangle do not overlap, so therefore C cannot be correct. A is an assumption as not being paid well is not the same as being underpaid (you could be paid normally or adequately too).

stems.text: The following diagram shows the number of employees in different companies, Wyatt’s Water, Cuppo’s Chairs, Lenny’s Lighting and Dillon’s Desks. Employees sometimes work for multiple companies.

questions.text: Which companies has the most employees?
questions.explanation: Cuppo’s Chairs = 33, Wyatt’s Water = 31, Lenny’s Lightning = 32, Dillon’s Desks = 31. Therefore, the correct answer is B, Cuppo’s Chairs.

stems.text: A rally remote control car race is going to happen. Cars can be equipped with Rockets, Blades or Spikes to damage other cars. Twice as many cars have Rockets than those with Blades. Half the amount of cars with Spikes have Blades. The same number of cars have Rockets as Spikes.

questions.text: Which of the following represents this information?
questions.explanation: The top left represents Spikes (24 total), the bottom circle represents Blades (12 total), and the top right circle represents Rockets (24 total). Therefore, the correct answer is C.

stems.text: Dan tosses a coin 3 times, with a 50% chance of landing on heads or tails. He tosses the coin for the first time, but does not look at the coin which has tails facing upwards. Is Dan correct in stating that there is a 25% chance of getting all three tosses as tails?

options: Yes, both heads and tails have an equal 0.5 chance of landing
Yes, as the first toss was tails, the chance of getting the next two as tails as well is 0.25
No, the probability of getting all three tosses as tails is 0.125
No, Dan does not really have enough information to decide
questions.explanation: Given that he does not look, his prediction is not influenced by what the outcome of his first toss is. Therefore the probability of getting all 3 tosses as tails is 0.5*0.5*0.5 = 0.125. Therefore, the correct answer is C (25% would be correct if he had seen that the first toss showed tails, but he didn’t see it).

stems.text: Steph and Jocelyn play a game of tossing dice. If they land on an even number facing up on the dice, they get 1 point. If an odd number is facing up once they roll, they do not get anything. The winner gets the most points Steph has 3 turns, and Jocelyn has already rolled a 4, 5, and 2. Which of the following must be true?

options: In order to win, Steph needs to get even numbers on each roll
Steph has a 2/3 chance of beating Jocelyn
If Steph rolls a 6 as her first roll, she cannot win
If Steph rolls an odd number on her last roll, she will win anyway
questions.explanation: Option B is incorrect because she has 2/3 chance of drawing, not winning. In order to win, she needs all 3 to be even (therefore options C and D are incorrect). Therefore, the correct answer is A.

stems.text: A drug testing company decides to test its new drug on a sample of 200 people. Half the sample received a placebo, and of the remaining people, 20% experienced side effects and 1 in 10 people said they felt no effect. The company cannot market their drug if there is equal to or more than a 1/10 chance of side effects occurring in the overall sample. Based off this information, can the company market their drug?

options: Yes, the drug is safe as less than half experienced side effects
Yes, less than 1/10 people experienced side effects
No, 40 people in the sample experienced side effects, which is more than 20 people
No, 10% of people experienced side effects in the sample
questions.explanation: 20 people experienced side effects (20% of 100 people, since the group was split in half), and 20 people is 10% of the broader sample of 200. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

stems.text:
Two hospitals, A and B, are being surveyed for their bed quality and capacity. Hospital A has 300 beds, but only 80% are in usable condition.
Hospital B has 250 beds, but only 10% are in unusable condition.
Which hospital would be better if lots of patients suddenly came in needing beds?

options: A, because it has more usable beds
A, because only 60 beds are unusable
B, because a lower percentage of beds are unusable
B, because 90% of its beds are in usable condition
questions.explanation: Hospital A has 0.8*300 = 240 usable beds. Hospital B has 0.90*250 = 225 usable beds. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

stems.text: 3 students attend lectures. The probability of Student A attending a lecture is 3/5, Student B is 40% and Student C is 0.5. A lecture is scheduled for next Monday. What is the probability all 3 students attending this?

options: There is not enough information to calculate this probability
questions.explanation: The combined probability of them all turning up is 0.6*0.4*0.5 = 0.12. Note that 3/25 = 0.12. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

stems.text: A study was conducted in the UK investigating the favourite superhero of children from the ages of 1-5 for a particular TV show. The TV show features 4 different superheroes and children were asked who their favourite was. The results are shown in the bar graph below:

questions.text: Which is the most favourite superhero amongst children between the ages of 1-4?
questions.explanation: By observation, we can see that Mighty Man is the highest overall (but if you calculate it, Mighty Man = 48, and the closest competitor, Speedy Sally = 41). Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: What is the average number of children from each age group who picked Tornado Terry or Valiant Vanessa as their favourite superhero?
questions.explanation: Tornado Terry + Valiant Vanessa across all age groups = 61. Thus, the average across all 5 age groups = 61/5 = 12.2. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: What was the difference between the average number of 1-3 year olds who chose Mighty Man as their favourite as compared to the average number of 4-5 year olds who chose Speedy Sally as their favourite?
questions.explanation: Average no. of 1-3 year olds who chose Mighty Man = 35/3 = 11.66… . Average no. of 4-5 year olds who chose Speed Sally = 15/2 = 7.5. Thus, there is a 11.66… - 7.5 = 4.166… child difference, favouring Mighty Man. Therefore, the closest correct answer is B.

questions.text: How many children were surveyed in total?
questions.explanation: Mighty Man = 48, Speedy Sally = 41, Tornado Terry = 30, Valiant Vanessa = 31. Thus, 48 + 41 + 30 + 31 = 150 children total.

stems.text: The sales made in July and August by a phone company are shown below. The bar graph details the number of sales made in each of these months across each of the 4 weeks of the month.

questions.text: What were the average sales per week during July?
questions.explanation: Average July weekly sales = (500 + 800 + 700 + 900)/4 = 725 sales. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: What is the difference in average sales per week during August as compared to July?
questions.explanation: Average July weekly sales = (500 + 800 + 700 + 900)/4 = 725 sales. Average August weekly sales = (800 + 900 + 600 + 800)/4 = 775 sales. Thus, the difference is 50 sales, in favour of August. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: What were the average sales across July and August per week?
questions.explanation: Average July weekly sales = (500 + 800 + 700 + 900)/4 = 725 sales. Average August weekly sales = (800 + 900 + 600 + 800)/4 = 775 sales. Thus, the average weekly sales for both = (725 + 775)/2 = 750 sales. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If the actual number of sales for Week 4 in August was actually 840, how much do the average sales during August increase by?
questions.explanation: We can calculate the increase in Week 4 for August to be 840 – 800 = 40 sales. Thus, if we divide 40 by 4 weeks, we can figure out by how much the original average increases by: 40/4 = 10 sales. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

stems.text: Jack is conducting a raffle at his local charity event. He has made a list of prize items he purchased earlier and the price he purchased them for:

questions.text: How much did Jack spend on the prizes?
questions.explanation: 174 + 37 + 55 + 81 + 100 = $447. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If Jack meets the sales target, how much profit will he make?
questions.explanation: Sales target of 450 tickets means he wants to earn 450*1.75 = $787.50 in total. If the total cost of all the prizes is 174 + 37 + 55 + 81 + 100 = $447, then the profit = 787.50 – 447 = $340.50. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: The following week, all bats are on sale for 35% off. How much more profit could Jack have made if he had bought the prizes the next week?
questions.explanation: This means that the baseball AND cricket bat are reduced by 35% (so they are 65% of their original value next week). Thus, the new prices of the cricket bat and baseball bat respectively would be 174*0.65 = $113.10 and 100*0.65 = $65. Therefore, the new total cost of all the prizes = 113.10  + 37 + 55 + 81 + 65 = $351.10. Given the total money gained from the tickets = 450*1.75 = $787.50, the new profit would = 787.50 – 351.10 = $436.40. Since the original profit was $340.50 (Q2, but can be calculated again), we can deduce that he would earn 436.40 – 340.50 = $95.90 more. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: How many raffle tickets must Jack sell to make a profit of $500?
questions.explanation: If his costs are 174 + 37 + 55 + 81 + 100 = $447, and he wants a $500 profit, he needs to raise $947. Thus, he would need 947/1.75 = 541.14… = 542 tickets to be sold (not 541, because he still needs 0.14 tickets to be sold, and since you can’t have 0.14 tickets we have to round up to a full extra ticket). Therefore, the correct answer is C.

stems.text: Jerry owns 5 horses: Jack of Spades, Farlap, White Peach, Peppermint and Glory. His friend John has a horse, Comet, with an average speed of 5.2 miles per hour. They decide to go racing at a racecourse near their house which extends a length of 17 km through scenic woodland. Note: 1 mile = 1.6km

questions.text: Jerry rides Farlap for the full length of the racecourse in 85 minutes. What is its average speed in miles per hour?
questions.explanation: If the course is 17km = 17/1.6 = 10.625 miles, using the s = d/t formula, we can find that s = 10.625/1.4166… = 7.5 miles/hr (85 minutes is 1.41666…hrs). Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: How long does it take Comet to complete 3 lengths of the racecourse?
questions.explanation: The course is 17km = 17/1.6 = 10.625 miles. If Comet travels at 5.2mph, then using t = d/s, we know that t = 10.625/5.2 = 2.043269…hrs = 122.59… minutes per lap. Given he is doing 3 laps, it will take him 367.788… minutes, which rounds to 367.8 minutes. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: Jack of Spades has an average speed 1.4 mph faster than Comet, and Glory completes a length 24 minutes faster than Jack of spades. What is Glory’s speed in miles per hour?
questions.explanation: The course is 17km = 17/1.6 = 10.625 miles. We can tell that Jack of Spades’ average speed = 1.4 + 5.2 = 6.6mph. This means he would complete the racecourse in t = d/s = 10.625/6.6 = 1.6098…hrs = 96.59… minutes. If Glory completed the course in 24 minutes less, that means she completed it in 72.5909… minutes = 1.2098…hrs. Thus, Glory’s average speed would be been s = d/t = 10.625/1.2098… = 8.782…mph = 8.8mph. Therefore, the closest correct answer is A.

questions.text: If Peppermint gives Comet a 32-minute head start, they both finish 2 lengths of the racecourse at the same time. What is Peppermint’s average speed in kilometres/hour?
questions.explanation: The course is 17km = 17/1.6 = 10.625 miles. If Comet travels at 5.2mph, then using t = d/s, we know that t = 10.625/5.2 = 2.043269…hrs = 122.59… minutes per lap. Given Comet completed 2 lengths, he would have taken 245.192… minutes in total. If Peppermint takes 32 minutes less to complete the same distance at the same finishing time as Comet, then we can deduce that Peppermint took 245.192… - 32 = 213.1923... minutes = 3.55…hrs in total. Thus, we can calculate that Peppermint’s speed = d/t = (10.625*2)/3.55… = 5.98… mph. In kilometres/hour, this would be 5.98…*1.6 = 9.5688… = 9.6km/h. Therefore, the closest correct answer is B.

stems.text: Each year, the American government keeps a record of the racial composition of the country. Below is a chart showing which racial backgrounds made up the country’s population in 2017.

questions.text: Which was the most represented race in the USA in 2017?
questions.explanation: Hispanic has the largest proportion of the population in the chart (45.4%) and on observing the chart as well. Therefore, the correct answer is D.

questions.text: If there were 30.2 million African American people in the USA in 2016, assuming the population proportions remained the same from 2016-2017, how many were American Indian?
questions.explanation: Total USA population in 2016 = 30.2 million/0.093 = 324.73… million. Thus, the population of American Indians = 0.004*324.73… = 1.2989… million = 1.3 million. Therefore, the correct closest answer is A.

questions.text: What was the total Hispanic population in the USA in 2018?
questions.explanation: In 2017, the Hispanic population would have = 0.454*325.1 million = 147.5954 million. If the population decreased by 0.8% from 2017-18, then the 2018 Hispanic population would be 147.5954*0.992 = 146.414637 million = 146.4 million. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: What was the total Asian/Pacific population in 2018?
questions.explanation: If the USA’s population increased from 325.1 million in 2017 to 2018 by 0.1%, then the population in 2018 would have been 325.4251 million. Thus, the Asian/Pacific population in 2018 would be 325.4251*0.089 = 28.96… million = 29.0 million rounded. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

stems.text: The line graph below shows the expenditure of the UK government per pupil in average daily attendance for 6 school years starting in 1977. Both the expenditure in unadjusted dollars and constant dollars is shown.

questions.text: What is the total expenditure of the UK government per student for the 6 school years combined in constant 2004-05 dollars?
questions.explanation: 6.1 + 6.2 + 7.7 + 8.4 + 9.1 + 9.9 = 47.4 thousand = 47,400 dollars. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

questions.text: By what percentage is the total expenditure per student in constant 2004-05 dollars greater than the total expenditure per student in unadjusted dollars for the 20th century?
questions.explanation: 20th century = 1977 to 1998 in this graph (ie. not 2002/03). Therefore, the total expenditure per student in unadjusted dollars = 2 + 3.2 + 4.6 + 6.2 + 7.7 = 23.7 thousand dollars. The total expenditure per student in adjusted 2004/05 dollars = 6.1 + 6.2 + 7.7 + 8.4 + 9.1 = 37.5 thousand dollars. Thus, the percentage difference is (37.5 – 23.7)/23.7 * 100 = 58.2%. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: The total expenditure per student for 2006-07 is projected to increase by 420% from 1987-88. What is the predicted expenditure per student for 2006-07 in unadjusted dollars?
questions.explanation: Predicted expenditure per student = 4.6 * 4.20 = 19.32 thousand dollars in 2006/07.  Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: If there were 32,000 students in 1982-83 which increased by 11.7% by 1987-88, what was the total expenditure in constant 2004-05 dollars in 1987-88?
questions.explanation: Students in 1987-88 = 1.117*32,000 = 35,744. Thus, the total expenditure = 35,744*7.7 = 275,228.80 thousand dollars = $275,228,800. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

stems.text:
A chemist working in a lab uses a tank to create solutions. The tank has the following dimensions: Length 50cm, Width: 0.3m, Height: 20cm
Note: 1L = 1dm^3 where 1 dm = 10cm

questions.text: What is the volume of the tank?
questions.explanation: Volume = 50*30*20 = 30,000cm^3. In dm^3, this would be 30dm^3 = 30L. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: The chemist makes a 10,000cm^3  hydrochloric acid solution with a concentration of 12g/L. What is the weight of the solution in grams?
questions.explanation: 10,000cm^3 = 10dm^3 = 10L. Thus, 12*10 = 120g. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: The chemist fills the tank up to a height of 15.3cm. He lets it freeze overnight. The volume of liquid water in the tank decreases to 15.5L. By what percentage has the water level dropped?
questions.explanation: Originally, the volume of water would be 15.3*30*50 = 22,950cm^3 = 22.95dm^3 = 22.95L. If the volume of liquid water drops to 15.5L, the percentage decrease in water volume = (22.95 – 15.5)/22.95 * 100 = 32.46… = 32.5%. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: In the tank, the chemist pours 4800 cubic cm of pure water with an oxygen concentration of 91%.  He also adds 3 goldfish. What is the average quantity of oxygen per fish?
questions.explanation: The volume of oxygen in the tank would be 0.91*4800 = 4,368cm^3 = 4.368dm^3 = 4.368L. Thus, there would be 4.368/3 = 1.456L of oxygen per fish. Therefore, the closest correct answer is A.

stems.text: The table below shows the ratio of water to fruit juice for 5 different drinks.

questions.text: If all the drinks are only made from water and fruit juice, which drink contains the largest amount of fruit juice?
questions.explanation: Starting with Apple Cider, we can calculate the amount of fruit juice to be (2/5)*185 = 74mL. Thus, we can eliminate Red Mocktail and Pink Peach, which have total amounts of water + fruit juice of 40mL and 70mL, both less than 74mL. Looking at the only remaining option, Orange Juice, the amount of fruit juice = (3/4)*230 = 172.5mL. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: Which drink contains the largest volume of water?
questions.explanation: Volume of water in Apple Cider = (3/5)*185 = 111mL. Thus, we can eliminate Red Mocktail and Pink Peach, which have total amounts of water + fruit juice of 40mL and 70mL, both less than 111mL. Volume of water in Apple Juice = (4/5.5)*155 = 112.72…mL, which is greater than 111mL. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: What is the total ratio of fruit juice to water for all the apple drinks combined?
questions.explanation: The distribution of water:fruit juice for Apple Cider = 111:74. The distribution of water:fruit juice for Apple Juice = 112.72… :42.27… . Adding them together, we get 223.72… : 116.27 … = 1: 1.924… = 1: 1.92. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: How much more water is present in the juice drinks compared to the mocktail
questions.explanation: Water in Apple Juice = (4/5.5)*155 = 112.72…mL. Water in Orange Juice = (1/4)*230 = 57.5mL. Together, that makes 170.272…mL in the juice drinks. Water in Mocktail = (2/7)*40 = 11.42…mL. Thus, the difference is 170.272… - 11.42… = 158.84… = 159mL. Therefore, the correct answer is A.

stems.text: James wishes to re-lawn a circular patch in his garden. The circular patch has a diameter of 8 metres. Note that the radius is half the diameter. There are 2 landscapers whom he can choose from and the material costs and labour costs are given below for each landscaper:

questions.text: What is the area of the circular strip in James’ garden in square metres?
questions.explanation: If the diameter is 8m, the radius will be 4m. Thus the area of circle = 3.141875*4*4 = 50.27 sq metres. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: If James uses Jim’s Landscapers to re-lawn his garden, how much will it cost in total?
questions.explanation: If the diameter is 8m, the radius will be 4m. Thus the area of circle garden = 3.141875*4*4 = 50.27 sq metres. Total costs for Jim’s Landscapers would be $6 per square metre, which means James will have to pay 50.27*6 = $301.62. Therefore, the correct answer is C.

questions.text: James has a budget of $350. By what percentage will Mowing Madness’ differ from his budget?
questions.explanation: If the diameter is 8m, the radius will be 4m. Thus the area of circle garden = 3.141875*4*4 = 50.27 sq metres. Total costs for Mowing Madness would be $8 per square metre, which means James will have to pay 50.27*8 = $402.16. This would be 402.16 – 350 = $52.16 more than his budget. Thus, as a percentage, it would be (52.16/350)*100 = 14.9% more than his budget. Therefore, the correct answer is B.

questions.text: If James decides to place a circular fountain of radius 1.78m in the middle of the circular patch in the garden, what area (in sq. metres) of the patch he wishes to re-lawn will be covered in lawn?
questions.explanation: If the diameter of the whole garden is 8m, the radius will be 4m. Thus the area of outer circle garden = 3.141875*4*4 = 50.27 sq metres. The circular fountain area = 3.141875*1.78*1.78 = 9.95471675… square metres. Therefore, the actual area of lawn he has in the garden to re-lawn would be 50.27 – 9.95471675… = 40.315… = 40.32 square metres. Therefore, the correct answer is A.
