stems.text: Chris, a student, is chatting with his friend during a tutorial when the lecturer tells him to be quiet. Taken aback, Chris tells the lecturer that he wasn’t happy with the way he said that.  The lecturer then mutters a personal insult to Chris under his breath. Chris and Chris’ friend, John, hear this and Chris appears to be offended. How appropriate are each of the following responses by John in this situation?

questions.text: Challenge the lecturer immediately about his comment
questions.explanation: Challenging the lecturer will only fuel further conflict and disrupt the lesson further

questions.text: Inform the academic supervisor about the incident
questions.explanation: It is appropriate to raise this matter with the supervisor and s/he can choose how to deal with the situation

questions.text: Ask other students about their opinion on this
questions.explanation: While this may help gain further insight into the issue, it is up to Chris whether he wishes to pursue this further

questions.text: Do not take any further action
questions.explanation: While not taking action may help diffuse the situation, Chris is evidently upset and the tutor’s behaviour is not acceptable. It should be up to Chris whether he wishes to pursue this further

questions.text: Console Chris and ask how he is feeling
questions.explanation: As a friend, John should seek to ensure that Chris is ok and seek to comfort him

stems.text: When conducting a medical interview of a patient, Maria is asked by the patient about treatments to help her with her shoulder pain. The patient mentions a new medication that Maria has never heard of and asks her opinion on this to treat shoulder pain. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Maria in this situation?

questions.text: Ask the patient more about her shoulder pain and what she’s doing for it
questions.explanation: Addressing patient concerns is the major priority for doctors and Maria should seek to get as much information as possible about the patient’s concerns

questions.text: Suggest that the patient uses a standard pain relief medication
questions.explanation: As a medical student, Maria is not qualified to provide this kind of advice

questions.text: Suggest that the patient should not use the new medication if there is a risk of side effects
questions.explanation: As a medical student, Maria is not qualified to provide this kind of advice

questions.text: Take note of this and suggest that the patient asks her GP (who is also in the room)
questions.explanation: It is definitely appropriate for Maria to direct the patient to a more qualified individual to resolve her concerns

questions.text: Inform the patient that she is not qualified to comment/recommend any medications
questions.explanation: Yes, as a medical student, Maria is not qualified to provide this kind of advice; however, she can offer to pass on her query to the GP

stems.text: Dr Sangha enters the treating room to see a patient irate. The patient complains that he’s been waiting almost an hour to see doctor and the nurse was ignoring his requests. The nurse is also in the room. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Dr Sangha in this situation?

questions.text: Apologise on behalf of the nurse
questions.explanation: By apologising, Dr Sangha would be accepting the patient’s claims that the nurse was ignoring him without actually first establishing the facts

questions.text: After he’s finished treating the patient, privately ask the nurse about her side of the story
questions.explanation: Before jumping to a conclusion, the nurse’s perspective should be heard (not in front of the patient however)

questions.text: Apologise about the fact that he was running late
questions.explanation: It is professional behaviour to apologise to patients if they have had to wait to see a doctor

questions.text: Ignore the patient’s concerns and begin with the consultation
questions.explanation: It is important for the doctor to acknowledge and investigate the patients concerns and rectify any mistakes so that this does not happen again

questions.text: Tell the patient to calm down and not raise his voice
questions.explanation: This will only frustrate the patient and escalate the situation

stems.text: While shadowing a senior doctor, a junior doctor observes the senior doctor using condescending language and making a number of perceivably racist remarks towards the patient. The patient appears to laugh it off. How appropriate are each of the following responses by the junior doctor in this situation?

questions.text: Tell the senior doctor in front of the patient that his behaviour is wrong
questions.explanation: It is entirely inappropriate to directly challenge the doctor in front of a patient. Even if the junior doctor found the comments offensive, he should go about the issue in a less confrontational manner

questions.text: Tell the senior doctor that he believes such language is inappropriate
questions.explanation: It is appropriate and advisable to wait until after the consult before bringing up the issue with the senior doctor

questions.text: Talk to another trusted and senior member of staff about the junior doctor’s language
questions.explanation: Rather than directly approaching the senior doctor, it may also be appropriate to talk to another senior member of staff to tactfully decide how to deal with the situation

questions.text: Make a complaint to the hospital about the senior doctor’s language
questions.explanation: While not entirely inappropriate, the junior doctor should first try to resolve the situation at a local level before escalation

questions.text: Privately ask the patient if he is ok with those comments that were made
questions.explanation: It is reasonable for the junior doctor to check in with the patient to make sure that they are not offender nor uncomfortable

stems.text: Julie, a medical student, recently submitted her coursework assignment for grading. Her friend, Brian missed the deadline and is now asking for Julie to send through her assignment – just for inspiration. Brian has a history of academic misdemeanours. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Gavin in this situation?

questions.text: Share her content notes on the assignment topic to Brian but not the assignment itself
questions.explanation: Rightfully concerned that Brian may plagiarise her work, it is justifiable for Julie to help out Brian through this way instead

questions.text: Suggest that Brian discusses his difficulties completing the assignment with the tutor
questions.explanation: It is entirely appropriate for Julie to refer Brian to the academic tutor if she is in any doubt

questions.text: Be a good friend and send Brian her assignment
questions.explanation: It is highly inappropriate, and often against university policy to send around assignments. Brian may copy Julie’s assignment and get her into trouble too

questions.text: Offer to complete the assignment for Brian
questions.explanation: It is entirely inappropriate and often against university policy for a student to write an assignment for another student – this undermines the whole assessment process

questions.text: Suggest that Brian perhaps requests an extension on the assignment
questions.explanation: While an extension should be requested, this should have been requested much before the due date

stems.text: Three medical students, Janette, Mary and Bill, have been tasked with taking a thorough history of a patient to practice their history taking skills. They agreed to split up the interview into thirds, swapping the role of the interviewer in each third. Janette starts but doesn’t swap over at the interval and keeps talking. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Mary and Bill in this situation?

questions.text: Allow Janette to continue, but ask her afterwards about how she should have swapped as initially planned
questions.explanation: While it is good not to abruptly interrupt Janette, in order to avoid confrontation, the other students will miss out on a valuable chance to practice

questions.text: Ask the patient for them to be excused and privately remind Janette that it is time to swap
questions.explanation: The discussion doesn’t occur in front of the patient and this ensures all students have a chance to practice

questions.text: Inform the academic supervisor that Janette didn’t give them a chance to contribute
questions.explanation: This is a minor issue that should be resolved locally rather than immediately involving more senior staff

questions.text: Tell Janette to stop in front of the patient
questions.explanation: While this will ensure they both have a chance to practice, abruptly telling Janette to stop is not a good course of action

questions.text: Don’t say anything
questions.explanation: This does not display good communication, Janette might’ve only needed a reminder, and, consequently, will mean that the other students miss out on a learning opportunity

stems.text: Christopher, a university student, is working with a group on an assignment that contributes to their coursework. One member, Heather, volunteers herself to be the group leader and appears to be dominating group discussions. She adopts most of the roles and work that needs to be completed and is not allowing the others to contribute. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Christopher in this situation?

questions.text: Tell Heather that she will have to leave the team if she keeps this up
questions.explanation: This is a confrontational approach and Christopher doesn’t have the authority to simply remove a group member from the team

questions.text: Seek advice from the academic tutor
questions.explanation: While this may help, the issue should be resolved within the group first before escalating to a member of staff

questions.text: Let Heather complete most of the work so that he does have to
questions.explanation: This is a team environment, and everyone should be contributing – they may miss out on a valuable learning opportunity otherwise

questions.text: Encourage everyone else in the team to provide their thoughts and contributions to the assignment
questions.explanation: Doing so will help engage the whole group and maintain the team balance in a subtle way

questions.text: Complain about Heather to the other group members
questions.explanation: This is highly inappropriate, it will only sour relationships in the group and further increase division

stems.text: A medical student is at the bedside of a patient who overdosed on tablets. The doctor has recommended that the patient remain in hospital overnight to monitor her status. When the doctor leaves, the patient insists that she has to leave the hospital immediately. How appropriate are each of the following responses by the medical student in this situation?

questions.text: Suggest that she vocalises her concerns to the doctor when he returns
questions.explanation: While it is appropriate to recommend that the patient waits for the consultant and the student is not qualified to make any recommendations; the student should also remind the patient of the doctor’s advice

questions.text: Tell the patient to ask the nurse whether she can leave
questions.explanation: The doctor has clearly provided advice and the nurse is not responsible for deciding whether this patient can or cannot leave

questions.text: Tell the patient that she must stay overnight at the hospital
questions.explanation: While this does pass on the doctor’s message, a patient cannot be held against their will un a hospital – this is only a firm recommendation

questions.text: Explain to the patient that the doctor has recommended that she stays in the hospital overnight
questions.explanation: Reinforcing the advice of the doctor is the most appropriate course of action

questions.text: Tell the patient that she is free to leave as she has the right to autonomy
questions.explanation: The directly contradicts the doctor’s advice and, while she does have the right to autonomy, the doctor’s advice should be repeated

stems.text: A GP, Murphy, is at his desk writing notes when he is approached by a patient, Ann, who says that she has been waiting for over an hour. Murphy is fully booked with appointments today and is not running behind. Murphy suspects that the reception staff may have double-booked one of his appointment slots. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Murphy in this situation?

questions.text: Ask the receptionist about what has happened
questions.explanation: It is essential to determine the facts about how the situation arose – so that this can be prevented in the future

questions.text: Rush the next patient's appointment and see Ann after that
questions.explanation: It would be inappropriate for Murphy to rush other appointments as this may compromise patient care

questions.text: Apologise to Ann for her wait
questions.explanation: It is highly appropriate to acknowledge the mistake and apologise to the patient for their wait

questions.text: Tell Ann to return home and rebook another day
questions.explanation: This response is highly insensitive and will only serve to upset Ann

questions.text: See whether any other doctors are free to see Ann – if Ann and the doctors are fine with this
questions.explanation: This will minimise the extra wait time for Ann without putting the burden on Murphy to see another patient

stems.text: Keith, a medical student, is shadowing a Dr, Dr Noah, as he sees a patient. While conversing with the patient, Dr Noah writes down notes on the patient’s allergies. Dr Noah receives a phone call and then has to leave the ward. When reviewing the notes, Keith realises that the patient is allergic to the medication that Dr Noah was planning to administer to the patient. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Keith in this situation?

questions.text: Delete the medication recommendation from the patient's notes
questions.explanation: It is very inappropriate for a medical student to alter medical records, especially when the doctor is not present

questions.text: Ask the nurse, who is personally going to administer the medication, to clarify what medication it is
questions.explanation: It is appropriate to discuss his concerns with the nurse is appropriate; however, it would be more appropriate to discuss this with the doctor as a matter of urgency

questions.text: Leave a not on the desk for when Dr Noah returns
questions.explanation: This is highly inappropriate as this may allow the prescription to be administered by then – despite the suspected allergy

questions.text: Do nothing as Dr Noah may have written down the medication under allergies by accident
questions.explanation: It is incorrect to assume this is the case – if there is a suspected allergy, this should be dealt with immediately

questions.text: Ask a passing senior consultant, who is free, for help immediately
questions.explanation: If Dr Noah cannot be reached, it is appropriate for Keith to seek advice from a senior member of staff as a matter of urgency

stems.text: A junior doctor, Reshan, has been called urgently to tend to a patient in another ward. However, earlier in the day, Reshan recalls the supervisor saying that he should stay in the one ward during the day. The ward he is currently in is very busy; however, he has urgently been called to attend to another patient. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Reshan when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: That the other doctors in the ward may struggle if he leaves
questions.explanation: It is important to consider the workload of other members in the team, however the urgency of the request and the potential consequences should be considered

questions.text: His supervisor's instructions
questions.explanation: It is always essential for junior doctors to head their supervisors’ advice

questions.text: That there are other patients he has to tend to in this ward
questions.explanation: This is his primary duty and should be conserved -  he must ensure that adequate cover is in place if he leaves

questions.text: That there is no one else that can tend to the urgent patient
questions.explanation: This is an extremely important consideration as leaving the patient unattended could have serious consequences

questions.text: Taking a while to think about a measured approach
questions.explanation: While it is important to come up with a measured response, time is of the essence and Reshan must respond in a timely fashion

stems.text: During a tutorial, one student, Harry is constantly interrupting the tutor, making many silly comments and constantly interrupting the lesson. The tutor looks very stressed and another student, Eugene, is struggling to concentrate. How important to take into account are the following considerations for Eugene when deciding how to respond to the situation?

questions.text: The impact of Harry’s behaviour on the tutor
questions.explanation: In disturbing the tutor and his emotional stat, Harry will inevitably impact the delivery of content and other students

questions.text: Harry’s reaction if Eugene tells him to stop
questions.explanation: This is not an important consideration as Eugene’s learning is being affected and his actions are having a wider impact on the class. He could intervene in a less confrontational way to prevent further disruptions

questions.text: The impact on the students’ learning
questions.explanation: Harry’s actions will affect all students who are in attendance and so it is very important to consider this

questions.text: Whether the tutor can handle this independently
questions.explanation: Whether or not the tutor can deal with the situation himself is an important consideration, however, regardless, action should be taken to improve the learning environment

questions.text: That Eugene can just revise the content when he gets home
questions.explanation: The tutorial should be an interactive learning opportunity for all and Eugene should take action to safeguard the students’ learning – not just resign to Harry’s disruptive behaviour

stems.text: Jessica is a medical student who has set up a social justice club for medical students. She tells all members that meetings are at 8PM on Mondays. The day after the first meeting, a member, Jim, approaches Jessica complaining that she was unable to enter the building upon arriving at 8.30. Jessica locked the doors of the building at 8.20 to prevent any interruptions to the meetin. How appropriate are each of the following responses by Jessia in this situation?

questions.text: I’m very sorry – I would never try to exclude you
questions.explanation: This is a great way to placate the situation and reassure Jim of her good intentions

questions.text: I’ll look into arrangements to accommodate late arrivers
questions.explanation: This will placate Jim as it shows that she is keen on putting into place initiatives that will avoid the problem from happening again in the future

questions.text: I'm sorry, can you tell me why you are upset
questions.explanation: While appropriate, it would be better to first vocalise her good intentions

questions.text: I’m sorry, I just assumed that locking the doors at 8.20 would be ok
questions.explanation: This will help placate Jim and ensures that Jessica isn’t imparting any blame on him

questions.text: You should try to be on time next time if you want to attend
questions.explanation: This comment is undeniably inflammatory and will only escalate the situation
